Award.AwardTitle: Tephra layers and early warning signals for critical transitions
Award.AbstractNarration: This project seeks to develop new measures of land surface resilience through a novel study of layers of volcanic ash (tephra). Changes in vegetation patterns are known to indicate changing land surface resilience and indicate proximity to threshold change. The morphology of cm-scale thicknesses of tephra is shaped by the pre-existing vegetation cover, in particular its depth, density, extent or patchiness. Thus, when tephra deposition is of a similar depth to the height of the pre-existing vegetation, tephra layer morphology can be used to assess relative land surface resilience at the time of tephra deposition. The researchers aim to develop new measures of resilience firstly through study of tephra layers created by recent Icelandic eruptions- the 2010 eruption of Eyjafjallajökull and the 2011 eruption of Grímsvötn. Secondly, they will apply the new understandings gained from the study of very recent ash falls to the natural archive presented by the numerous past tephra layers preserved within the soil. Measures of land surface resilience and indications of proximity to threshold-crossing could make important contributions to understanding the interplay of changes driven by people and by the environment, and to the evolving field of sustainability science. In southern Iceland up to 21 tephra layers have been deposited since the Norse settlement, and these layers are clearly separated by intervening layers of aeolian sediment. We know that landscapes in these areas have been subject to directional drivers of change (such as falling temperatures and increasing grazing pressures) that have pushed land surfaces close to, and at times across, tipping points between one persistent state and another. Knowledge of ?near misses? in the past derived from novel uses of tephra layers could help us to understand the circumstances under which communities backed away from the brink of change, and the tradeoffs between adaptation and resilience, short term and long term robustness, and the effects of cross-scale conjunctures. This project will involve an international, multidisciplinary team, combine theoretical and methodological innovation with fieldwork and laboratory analysis, and provide research opportunities for early career scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of volcanic ash (tephra) layers for chronology is well established both in proximal and distal areas. The ecological impacts of tephra falls are also well studied; the novelty of this project is in the way it assesses in detail how the morphology of tephra layers 1-10cm thick can be modified by the vegetation communities on which they fall, effectively identifying the impact of ecology on the preservation of thin tephra layers. This is important because tephra layers of this type may be spatially extensive (covering thousands of km2) and can account for the bulk of tephra-fall deposits from large, explosive eruptions. In addition, spatial patterns in vegetation communities may also contain early warning signals of critical transitions from one state to another. So if tephra layer morphology can preserve details of past surface vegetation communities, and patterns in those communities contain early warning signals of critical transitions, similar signals may be present in tephra layers themselves.

Our study identifies variations in tephra layer thickness at a landscape scale that are related to structural metrics of vegetation, with tephra layers under shrub patches significantly thicker than those outside the shrub canopy.  It also indicates that small-scale (metre and sub-metre) relationships can emerge in short-statured, structurally simple vegetation, where variations in vegetation height/density modify local wind fields and influence tephra retention. In contrast, the presence of an extensive closed shrub or tree canopy can reduce surface wind speeds in an even way, allowing tephra to mantle the ground surface. This is likely to decouple the eventual morphology of the tephra layer from the ground layer, resulting in a spatially homogeneous deposit. Thus our work shows how tephra layers may contain data on the past land surfaces that they also date. This has potentially significant implications in archaeology, geography and sustainability science as tephra layers may be able to track the effects of different patterns of both land management and climate change across cultural landscapes, and conceivable identify spatial patterns that contain early warning signals of critical transformations.

This work also has significant implication for volcanology because of the use of tephra layers preserved in the stratigraphy to reconstruct volumes of past volcanic eruptions and assess their risks, hazards and impacts. We can identify circumstances when tephra layers can thin in areas of short vegetation and thicken under taller vegetation. This has implications for the reconstruction of volcanic fallout across areas with strong vegetation gradients and where vegetation structure and height are patchy. The latest results from this project are available at http://www.nature.com/articles/srep37260
